reviewText:
Really fun game. Good to see it updated and finally on Steam :)
I recommend it to anyone who loves epic and very fast-paced pvp/team arena battles.
I also had a try at the solo challenge mode and had my ♥♥♥ kicked gloriously by the AI :)
I loved the art style, the music and the characters designs and their special attacks are unique and well... really cool :D

To sum up, beautiful content, multiple game modes and it is pretty cheap... worth it

reviewerDisplayName: c l e m s o n
reviewText: At the current state of the game I would not reccomend it. It seemed fun and good, but once you play the game its very different. I bought this game intending to play with friends, only to see there is no online multiplayer, but hopefully they can implement that. From what I've played, all the arena is is jumping on other player heads and collecting items. There are no basic attacks which kinda sucks. The map is also small, making the game either really easy or really hard.\n\nTL;DR From what I've seen so far I would not reccomend it, hopefully they can make it better by adding online multiplayer, who knows. What I'd say is to definetly not buy the game for full price, and only get it for a sale. (As of writing this review, this game is about 30 cents on the Humble Bundle store.)

reviewText: Fun concept but the AI makes this game practically unplayable. Once they get over your head, it's pretty much over as they track your every move perfectly. The enemies are numerous and have you exact moves and abilities plus perfect computer precision and in the case of the first level if you do somehow manage to spam enough to get the boss to his last life (same as yours plus infinite minions) he just sits on your spawn in instakill mode until you fail. Fantastic art but it's completely wasted on this game, I'm really dissapointed with this.

reviewText: So I will start off by saying... This game is not online. Now that it's out of the way.. I can safely say i am a huge fan of this game. If your roommates/siblings or family or whatever want to join in, this game can be a great deal  of fun. I had a blast with this game. The new challenge mode is incredibly difficult, but that keeps you wanting more for hours on end. Level one is the hardest... but that makes it all the more satisfying. reviewText:
I want to like this game. I really do. But I just can't.

First off, the mechanics. You jump on heads. Once in a while you get a power up that does one thing, or another. It's like a hyper-nerfed version of Smash Bros, with uninteresting blobs instead of the beloved Marios and Zeldas and Pikachus. I'm not lucky enough to have anyone to do local multiplayer with, and there is no online, and maybe singleplayer is just a really bad representation of what Jamsouls is, but a game centered around jumping on people just doesn't do it for me.

Second off, difficulty is not something I often complain about in games, but this one's just too hard. It's hard to the point of just not fun. Think about the arcade games of the 80s, and multiply it by fifteen. It took me almost an hour to beat just the first level, and when I finally did there was next to no satisfaction. One down. Do I want to keep going? No

reviewText:
It's a fun arena-style game, however it does have some issues.

1. No online multiplayer capability. Not a big deal if you have friends, but unless you and your friends hang out a lot in person, you lose a lot of the functionality of the game.

2. Echoing another reviewer, the main playstyle is to get to high ground and jump on your opponent. It kills a lot of the strategy a game like this could have had, and removes all ability for people to play skillfully instead of bashfully. This is a big killer in arena-style games for me, and maybe for you as well.

An absolute top of the arena where the primary attack is head-stomping does not work for games like this; it's the equivalent of camping in FPS games. Whether they change it to falling down brings you to the ceiling, or portals or entrances to the ceiling or floor scattered around - any change could potentially fix this issue. But no changes were made, and the game hasn't seen any sort of update since launch, and no developer interaction post-release.

I think there are some salvagable elements in this game, but it doesn't meet a standard for what I think arena games should meet. With no sign of developers or any meaningful community, save your money and find a game that is still supported and more-or-less balanced; Jamsouls isn't that game.
